problem: When $p(x) = Ax^5 + Bx^3 + Cx + 4$ is divided by $x - 3,$ the remainder is 11.  Find the remainder when $p(x)$ is divided by $x + 3.$
solution:
By the Remainder Theorem, $p(3) = 11,$ so
\[A \cdot 3^5 + B \cdot 3^3 + C \cdot 3 + 4 = 11.\]Then $A \cdot 3^5 + B \cdot 3^3 + C \cdot 3 = 7.$

Again by the Remainder Theorem, when $p(x)$ is divided by $x + 3,$ the remainder is
\begin{align*}
p(-3) &= A \cdot (-3)^5 + B \cdot (-3)^3 + C \cdot (-3) + 4 \\
&= -A \cdot 3^5 - B \cdot 3^3 - C \cdot 3 + 4 \\
&= -7 + 4 \\
&= \boxed{-3}.
\end{align*}
socratic_questions:
1. What is the Remainder Theorem and how is it useful in finding remainders when dividing polynomials?
2. How does the fact that the remainder is 11 when $p(x)$ is divided by $x-3$ help us in solving this problem?
3. What is the importance of finding $p(3)$ in this problem?
4. How can we use the information $p(3)=11$ to help us find the values of $A$, $B$ and $C$ in the polynomial $p(x)$?
5. Why do we evaluate $p(-3)$ when trying to find the remainder of $p(x)$ when divided by $x+3$?
6. What is the significance of the signs of the coefficients in the polynomial $p(x)$ when finding the remainder of $p(x)$ when divided by $x+3$?
